title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Who am I?







I am the inaugural director of the Dominguez Center for Data Science at Bucknell University.

This is my first administrative gig.

We are building it up to be the campus hub for data science practice, support, and community.
I also spend my days figuring out our relationship to AI.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science
text:
Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science

Have had sabbaticals with

The Forest Service Forest Inventory and Analysis Program
The Bureau of Labor Statistics

text: Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Some Reflections





I have been on the job market a few times and so have thoughts on how to put together a good packet.
Happy to compare and contrast the different roles I’ve held:

Assistant to associate professor at small liberal arts colleges
Teaching faculty at a research university
Administrator for a data science center

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Some Reflections





It is okay to move and it is okay to stay.

Don’t strive for the perfect fit.

The people you work with regularly are important.

You have less control over your departmental colleagues.
You have more control over your research collaborators.

Choose your service commitments wisely.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Course Sites
Main site:

A (private) GitHub Repository https://github.com/Bucknell-DATA306-F25/class-site

I will add all of you once you provide your GitHub username.

We will NOT use Moodle.

A learning objective of the course is to get comfortable with git/GitHub.

Make sure to check the Schedule page often.


Gradescope:


For turning in work.


Slack for course communication.

Make sure to check Slack at least once a day during the work week.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Learning Objectives
You will engage in collaborative, data science projects. Upon successful completion of this course, you will be able to:

Conduct a full data analysis project.
Communicate about your data work at a variety of levels and via a variety of formats including short presentations, longer presentations, and written reports.
Think statistically about data and research questions.
Collaborate on projects with a reproducible workflow.
Run a productive consulting meeting.
Undertake future projects with greater independence.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Research Tools

Will vary by project!
All have access to an RStudio Server via a Posit Cloud Workspace. Will use for some activities and demos.
We will use a GitHub Organization for collaborating and to ensure we have a version controlled workflow.

Make sure to become a Watcher of the course site.
I will also share a specific project site with each student.

Bring a laptop to class. Please check-in with me if this will be an issue.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Readings

We will read a variety of papers and book chapters.
Main textbook is “Communicating with Data: The Art of Writing for Data Science” by Deborah Nolan and Sara Stoudt.

There are extra copies in Taylor 212. These copies should NOT leave Taylor 212.

Readings will be posted to the schedule.

Reading reflections are due Mondays at 10pm.

First reflections are due Sept 1st. Will discuss in Thursday’s class.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Policies

Make sure to check the course site for policies related to regrades, late work, attendance, technology, accommodations.
But let’s talk AI…

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
AI Policy
While A.I. tools, such as ChatGPT, are being used to generate code, analyze data, and write essays, goals of this course are to develop your own ability to write code, to thoughtfully extract knowledge from data, and to communicate your findings.
You may use AI in these course activities:

Providing feedback on their writing. The original draft should be your work but you can ask for feedback from AI and incorporate that feedback into the revision.
Providing coding suggestions or revisions. You are responsible for understanding every line of code in your project, regardless of whether it was written by you, your project members, your mentor, or AI.
Brainstorming ideas for your project.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
AI Policy
You may not use AI in these ways:

Writing the initial draft or whole paragraphs of a writing assignment or your technical report.
Writing large blocks of code.


If you do use AI in your project or on an assignment, please include an AI citation that provides: prompt, AI tool, company, date.


If you are in doubt as to whether you are using AI appropriately in this course, I encourage you to meet with me for a discussion. Violations of this policy will be considered academic misconduct.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Projects
Each project charter has:

Team composition: Student researchers will be assigned later this week.
Project background: Short summary motivating the project.
Project goals: What the stakeholder mentor wants to accomplish.
Data: A brief description of the data for the project.
Desired deliverables: Vary by project but all include a well-documented repository, technical report, and a final presentation (Dec 15th 9am - 11am).
Roles and expectations for each person on the team.
Research plan
Communication


Please read over the project charters and complete the Background and Interest Survey by noon tomorrow!
